cab.content: - ... L^.:-..:....v..v'-..K'0farn3iV8268BOARD OF AGRICULTURE FOR SCOTLAND. \f REPORT for the week ending 1st October, 1919.I. AGRICULTURE.1, Defence of the Realm Regulation ,2iIn torch 1917 the Board entered the whole of the Home Farm of Hensol been uncultivated during the previous Agent to undertake its cultivation, ly advised that a new tenant had been and that the farm would in future be accordingly withdrew from possessionon and took possession of , Kirkcudbright, which had year, and appointed an The Board were subsequent-secured by the proprietor adequately cultivated. They at Whitsunday 1918.A claim for compensation, amounting in all to 394:7:8, was submitted on behalf of the proprietor, in respect of loss alleged to have been sustained as a result of the Boara-s action. After an inspection of the farm by a representative of the Board, and protracted negotiations with the proprietor^ Agents, an arrangement was eventually arrived at whereby the claimant agreed to accept 275 in full settlement of all claims against the Board in respect of their action. This amount has now been paid.2. Increased Food Production.In April last, the Board distributed a leaflet which gave particulars of a method of haymaking practised in Scandinavia. Enquiries are now being made through the Agricultural Executive Committees as.to whether any farmers in their districts have, during the past season, adopted the suggestions made In the leaflet.3. Wart Disease of Potatoes (Scotland) Order 1918.The above Order, which came into operation in the Autuwi of last year, prohibited, inter alia, the planting in small gardens and allotments in certain scheduled areas in Scotland of any variety of potatoes which has not been approved by the Board as immune from wart disease.Despite the faot that every effort was made by the Board during the planting season to bring the terms of the Order to the notice of all interested parties, there ia reason to believe that in a number of cases non-immune varieties have been planted. The Board are.taking steps with a view to instituting prosecutions in oases where it appears that there has been a wilful contravent-? ion of the Order. A case came recently to their notice in which a serious outbreak of Wart Disease occurred in a crop of potatoes of a non^immme variety which had been planted in a garden situation-ed In a scheduled area. The case was reported to the Crown Agent at whose instance proceedings were successfully instituted against the occupier of the garden in question. *4. Agricultural Costings Committee.In connection with the investigation about to be undertaken by the Agricultural Costings Committee into the cost of producing milk during the coming Winter on a number of typical dairy farms and in town dairies throughout Great Britain, the Board have asked Agricultural/ Agricultural Executive Committees in Scotland to make every endeavour to induce dairy farmers in their districts to assist in the scheme.5, Agricultural Colleges.The Board have intimated their consent to the payment to the permanent whole-time offioera of the Agricultural Colleges of a War Bonus at the rate approved by the Treasury! In the case of permanent Civil Servants,6. Agricultural ScholarahlggkDuring the week Grants of amounts varying from 5 to 9 per month were awarded to 38 selected ex*dffleers and men to enable them to undergo a course of instruction in tropical agriculture; with a view to obtaining appointments in the Colonies in connection with rubber plantlngi coiton growing, sugar planting, flax growing, etc. A number of the beneficiaries are attending a course of this description which commenced in Edinburgh University in April and termin-ates in March of neat year, the Summer Vacation being devot-ed to practical work on a farm. Bbe: remainder will attend Courses at Edinburgh and Aberdeen Universities, commencing this month and continuing until next June.Payment of the grants awarded is conditional upon satis^ factory reports of attendance and progress being received from the Deans ofbthe Faculty of Soience at the Universities! named.7. Training of Disabled Soldiers.Enquiries are being made the Board into Schemes fer the training of demobilised men in Pi&-keeping, curing, eto.1 at the establishment of ilir.* D. Bell, Brighton, Cupar, Fife, and In gardening at the gardens ;.ot the Hoddam JSstate. Dumfril' 6t Tuberculous Soldiers.The Board are in communication.with the Scottish Board I Healtii with a view to making provision for the training in 1 agriculture and allied subjects of tuberculous ex-service mei At present agricultural instruction is given as part of the curative treatment of men suffering from this affection, at the Royal Victoria Hospital, Polton, Midlothian and at Hair-! myrea Institution, Lanarkshire.II. COLLECTION OF STATISTICS AHD RETURNS RELATING TO AGKICUIdi MMMMMMMAnnual Agricultural Returns...A copy is appended of the Abstract of the Agricultural Returns which gives, besides the information already given in the Preliminary Statement, particulars of the areas of the prinoipal.crops and the numbers of live stook in each county and county district. Tnese figures are subject to revision. III. DS?g)demobilisation OF AGRICULTURAL WORKERS.Of the total number of 10,127 men applied for by the Board for demobilisation, reports show that 9290 men have been released to date.IV. LAND SETTLBMT.1. Applications for Small Holdings.The total number of applications from ex-service men up to 27th September is 2,266. Of these, 582 have been reported on.2. Small Holding Colonies Acts 1916-1918.A formal offer has been received from the Directorate of Lands to sell a portion of the War Department lands at Gretna; a valuation is being made,3. Congested Districts Board Act, 1897.A draft scheme for the farm of Armadale, Sutherland, to which the Board take entry at Martinmas next, has been prepared; it provides for enlargement of holdings for 61 applicants, but Is subject to revision.4. Small Landholders (Scotland) Aot, 1911.Ex-service men in Shetland have threatened illegal seizure of the Farm of Asta in the Tlngwall Valleyj the Board have asked the Secretary for Scotland to authorise a Scheme for the formation of Small Holdings on this farm at Martinmas next.
